body: I'm happy to remove the tests, if the overall  approach LGTY.  Wanted to verify before adding churn.
LGTM, merging

OK, I agree that something is off here.. the API needs a bit more clarification.
I'll close this for now and keep discussion in the dev-list.
Better yet, in the designated ticket [`BEAM-849`](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-849)

'Using context: Jenkins: Maven clean install --none--

I'll review after your additional changes.

I will add here what I told you in person:
Spark `Accumulator`s (which is what you use to implement distributed Metrics) do not guarantee `exactly-once` or a `commit` unless running in an ["action"](http://spark.apache.org/docs/1.6.3/programming-guide.html#actions) (explained [here](http://spark.apache.org/docs/1.6.3/programming-guide.html#accumulators)) which we currently don't use in the runner for various reasons.
Currently, the guarantee (or it's drawback) is that Accumulators (hence Metrics in the Spark runner) may over count.

I just pushed some fixes:
-  Fixed size estimation (estimation was done based on only one token range on only one node of the cluster). Now size estimation of the table is done  on the whole token ranges on all the nodes. The method is the same that the one in use in cassandra spark connector. I Also introduced a Partitioner class to deal with ranges depending on configured partitioner. Off course, I added the related Tests. 
=> But `testRead() `and `testSplitIntoBundles()` now fail because now that size estimation is correct, `splitIntoBundles()` creates n sources, but, as the split query is ignored as I mentioned in above comment, it duplicates dataset by n. Need to "mix" the split query and the user query as I mentioned (need a query parser)

- I also re-architectured the test suite (see details in git log)

This has been merged, could you please close it? (Apache doesn't give us write access to the repo to do so ourselves...)

Sorry for the confusion, I see it's a Test*Pipeline*, not Test*Runner*

I think the way to do this would be to override `TestPipeline.run()` to return `super(TestPipeline, self).run().wait_until_finished()`. We could make this behavior optional, but it should default to True.
Since we're on the topic, are we therefore explicitly making the decision that non-testing runners will not block on .run() by default? This makes the more common use case of .run() less intuitive.

Runners are free to block or not as they see fit. Revisiting this for all
SDKs is a bigger question.
